title: Rotational KE - cylinder spring and ramp

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students would like to determine the spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> of a spring. As shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, one end of the spring is attached to a wall and the other end of the spring is attached to a string. The string is wrapped around a horizontal cylinder of known rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>. The cylinder can rotate about a fixed horizontal axle with negligible friction.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that (1) uses the setup shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and (2) would allow the students to determine <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. The students do not have access to any devices that can measure force or mass. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

A group of students would like to determine the spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> of a spring. As shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, one end of the spring is attached to a wall and the other end of the spring is attached to a string. The string is wrapped around a horizontal cylinder of known rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>. The cylinder can rotate about a fixed horizontal axle with negligible friction.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that (1) uses the setup shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and (2) would allow the students to determine <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. The students do not have access to any devices that can measure force or mass. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be analyzed to determine <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>.

The students would like to verify the value of the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub C" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math> of the cylinder. With the cylinder removed from the axle shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the students measured its diameter <math alttext="D sub C equals 0.1000 meter" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1000</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> and its mass <math alttext="M sub C equals 2.00 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math>.

In a series of experimental trials, the cylinder was released from rest on a ramp from various heights <math alttext="delta y" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>y</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. In each trial, the cylinder rolled without slipping down the ramp and onto a horizontal floor. The students then measured the time <math alttext="t sub L" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> it took the cylinder to travel a distance <math alttext="L equals 3.00 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.</mn><mtext>00 m</mtext></mstyle></math> along the horizontal floor. The results of each experimental trial are shown in the table.

The students correctly determine that the relationship between \(\Delta y\) and \(t_L\) is given by: 

\(2M_Cg\Delta y=\left(\frac{I_C}{R_C^2}+M_C\right)\left(\frac{L^2}{t_L^2}\right)\)

The students create a graph with \(\Delta y\) plotted on the horizontal axis.

(c)

i. Indicate which measured or calculated quantity could be plotted on the vertical axis to yield a linear graph whose slope can be used to calculate an experimental value for the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub C" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>. You may use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities (including units) that are not already in the table. 

Horizontal axis: <math alttext="delta y" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>y</mi></math> Vertical axis: __________

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label the vertical axis, including units. 

iii. Draw a best-fit line to approximate the trend of the data plotted in part (c)(ii).

(d) Calculate an experimental value for the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub C" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>, using the line of best-fit you drew in Figure 3 in part (c)(iii).
